about_config.research_goal_paragraph: My primary research goal is to understand and build safe AI systems and use them to solve real-world problems. This has led me to work on a variety of subjects including mechanistic interpretability, compositionality, causality, healthcare ML, neuroscience AI, reinforcement learning, and diffusion models.

conferences.title: Learning What Matters: Steering Diffusion via Spectrally Anisotropic Forward Noise

conferences.title: A Complexity-Based Theory of Compositionality
conferences.summary: We connect algorithmic complexity to compositional learning, proving when neural networks learn to compose primitive concepts.
conferences.abstract: We propose a formal mathematical definition of representational compositionality grounded in algorithmic information theory. A compositional representation must satisfy three key properties: expressiveness (capturing complex information), symbolic structure (re-describable as discrete symbolic sequences with re-combinable parts), and semantic simplicity (the function connecting symbols to representation must be simple). We validate our framework through experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets, demonstrating how it unifies various perspectives from AI and cognitive science literature.

conferences.title: Geometric Signatures of Compositionality Across a Language Model's Lifetime
conferences.summary: We discover geometric signatures in language model representations that predict compositional generalization ability.
conferences.abstract: We investigate whether language models capture the inherent simplicity of language through compositionality by examining how dataset compositionality relates to the intrinsic dimension of model representations. We find that dataset compositionality is reflected in the intrinsic dimensionality of learned representations, with this relationship emerging through linguistic features developed during training. Nonlinear and linear dimensionality respectively encode semantic and superficial aspects of linguistic composition.

conferences.title: Expressivity of Neural Networks with Random Weights and Learned Biases
conferences.summary: We prove that neural networks can learn complex functions using only bias parameters while keeping weights random, characterizing the expressivity of this architecture

conferences.title: Delta-AI: Local Objectives for Amortized Inference in Sparse Graphical Models

conferences.title: Contrastive Retrospection: honing in on critical steps for rapid learning and generalization in RL
